dc:description:
The OFD1 protein is a key regulator of ciliogenesis, both of primary and motile cilia. It localizes primarily at centrioles and centriolar satellites, and basal bodies, and is involved in stabilizing centrioles and ensuring proper cilia assembly. Most reported OFD1 variants are loss of function (indels with frameshift) and are inherited in an X-linked dominant manner. OFD1 has been associated with 5 different diseases: Retinitis pigmentosa 23, Joubert syndrome 10 (XL-JS), Orofaciodigital syndrome I (OFD1), Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome, type 2 (SGBS2) and Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD). Intra-familial variability within these diseases has been reported and X inactivation studies have shown that skewed X inactivation could be partially involved in the pathogenesis of intrafamilial clinical variability.
OFD1 interacts with the LCA5-encoded protein lebercilin. Mutations in LCA5 cause the Leber's congenital amaurosis (LCA), a rare inherited eye disease. The destabilization of lebercilin in conditions of OFD1 deficiency might be the basis of Retinitis pigmentosa 23 diagnoses in these patients.
There is an inverse correlation between OFD1 mutant protein length and phenotypic severity, which could be explained by differences in binding to functionally interacting proteins and disruption of ciliary localization. All mutations before amino acid residue 631 are lethal for males and cause OFD1 syndrome in females. The SGBS2-associated p.E709fs mutation causes macrocephaly and early death in males but it leaves females unaffected. Male patients with the p.K948fs and p.E923fs mutations have JS and may live beyond the age of 30 years, whereas carrier females are not affected. In addition, variants in exons 20 and 21 have been associated with PCD with or without additional characteristics of JS, in male patients. To our knowledge, no female patients with PCD have been reported with variants in OFD1.
Based on this data, the ID/Autism EP and the Motile Ciliopathies GCEP decided to lump together the OFD1, SGBS2, XL-JS and PCD disease assertions under OFD1-related ciliopathy, a MONDO Disease Ontology that is inclusive of all four assertions. This decision has been made as OFD1 mutations cause Ciliopathy with differing severity of phenotype (OFD1 > SGBS2 > XL-JS > PCD, OFD1 being the most severe); the phenotype depends on the position of the stop codon. Early stop variants likely correspond with the absence of protein because of nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (MND).
Regarding the correlation of OFD1 and XLID, in Del Giudice et al. 2014 (PMID: 24884629) the authors identified patients displaying neurological symptoms and/or cognitive/behavioral abnormalities, brain structural anomalies in 88.7%, cognitive impairment in 68%, and associated neurological disorders and signs in 53% of cases. The most frequently observed structural brain anomalies included agenesis of the corpus callosum, neuronal migration/organization disorders, intracerebral cysts, porencephaly, and cerebellar malformations. The results from Del Giudice et al. 2014 support recently published findings indicating that CNS involvement in this condition is found in more than 60% of cases. Additionally, the authors described specific neuropsychological aspects such as reduced ability processing verbal information, slow thought process, difficulties in attention and concentration, and notably, long-term memory deficits which may indicate a specific role of OFD1 and/or primary cilia in higher brain functions. Thus the association of ODF1 and OFD1-related ciliopathy is definitive.

The OFD1 protein is a key regulator of ciliogenesis, both of primary and motile cilia. It localizes primarily at centrioles and centriolar satellites, and basal bodies, and is involved in stabilizing centrioles and ensuring proper cilia assembly. Most reported OFD1 variants are loss of function (indels with frameshift) and are inherited in an X-linked dominant manner. OFD1 has been associated with 4 different diseases: Retinitis pigmentosa 23, Joubert syndrome 10 (XL-JS), Orofaciodigital syndrome I (OFD1) and Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD). Simpson–Golabi–Behmel syndrome, type 2 has previously been associated with OFD1 (PMID: 16783569) but this association has been disputed (PMID: 29057530, 26545172) and has not been included in the lumped curation, pending further evidence. Intra-familial variability within these diseases has been reported and X inactivation studies have shown that skewed X inactivation could be partially involved in the pathogenesis of intrafamilial clinical variability. OFD1 interacts with the LCA5-encoded protein lebercilin. Mutations in LCA5 cause the Leber's congenital amaurosis (LCA), a rare inherited eye disease. The destabilization of lebercilin in conditions of OFD1 deficiency might be the basis of Retinitis pigmentosa 23 diagnoses in these patients. There is an inverse correlation between OFD1 mutant protein length and phenotypic severity, which could be explained by differences in binding to functionally interacting proteins and disruption of ciliary localization. All mutations before amino acid residue 631 are lethal for males and cause OFD1 syndrome in females. Male patients with the p.K948fs and p.E923fs mutations have JS and may live beyond the age of 30 years, whereas carrier females are not affected. In addition, variants in exons 20 and 21 have been associated with PCD with or without additional characteristics of JS, in male patients. To our knowledge, no female patients with PCD have been reported with variants in OFD1. Based on this data, the ID/Autism EP and the Motile Ciliopathies GCEP decided to lump together the RP, OFD1, XL-JS and PCD disease assertions under OFD1-related ciliopathy, a MONDO Disease Ontology that is inclusive of all four assertions. This decision has been made as OFD1 mutations cause Ciliopathy with differing severity of phenotype (OFD1 > XL-JS > PCD, OFD1 being the most severe); the phenotype depends on the position of the stop codon. Early stop variants likely correspond with the absence of protein because of nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (MND). Regarding the correlation of OFD1 and XLID, in Del Giudice et al. 2014 (PMID: 24884629) the authors identified patients displaying neurological symptoms and/or cognitive/behavioral abnormalities, brain structural anomalies in 88.7%, cognitive impairment in 68%, and associated neurological disorders and signs in 53% of cases. The most frequently observed structural brain anomalies included agenesis of the corpus callosum, neuronal migration/organization disorders, intracerebral cysts, porencephaly, and cerebellar malformations. The results from Del Giudice et al. 2014 support recently published findings indicating that CNS involvement in this condition is found in more than 60% of cases. Additionally, the authors described specific neuropsychological aspects such as reduced ability processing verbal information, slow thought process, difficulties in attention and concentration, and notably, long-term memory deficits which may indicate a specific role of OFD1 and/or primary cilia in higher brain functions. Thus the association of OFD1 and OFD1-related ciliopathy is definitive.

evidence.dc:description: Group decides to not score cases that have non-PCD symptoms.

In rat photoreceptor cells, both OFD1 and lebercilin
localize to the connecting cilium region, which is essentially
the ciliary transition zone (Figures 4J–4O). This
specific connecting cilium localization was evident from
costaining of both proteins with the cilium marker centrin.
evidence.rdfs:label: OFD1 and Lebercilin Colocalization in hTERT-RPE1 Cells and R

evidence.dc:description: 0.5 pt for expression, 0.5 pt for localisation

OFD1 is localised in control human lung and kidney ciliated cells. OFD1 mutant protein is expressed in patient airway cilia. In controls, OFD1 is retained in the basal body with centrin (marker). In patients, only a minority of basal bodies was anchored at the apical cellular membrane.
evidence.rdfs:label: OFD1 expression & localisation

evidence.dc:description:
To explain the phenotypic spectrum observed for OFD1
mutations, we tested whether six OFD1 mutations,
p.K948fs and p.E923fs (XL-JS; this report), p.I784fs
(OFD149), p.E709fs (SGBS228), p.N630fs (OFD150), and
p.S586fs (OFD127), affect interaction with lebercilin and/
or subcellular localization. In a yeast two-hybrid interaction
assay, the p.I784fs, p.N630fs, and p.S586fs mutations
completely disrupted interaction of OFD1 with the fragment
containing the predicted coiled-coil domains 1 and
2 of lebercilin, as evidenced by the fact that none of the
reporter genes for interaction were activated (Figure 5A).
For the p.E923fs mutant, yeast growth was significantly
reduced in comparison to wild-type OFD1 under conditions
selecting for interaction, indicating a reduced
binding affinity. The p.K948fs mutation only slightly
reduced yeast growth, whereas the p.E709fs mutation did
not apparently affect yeast growth.
evidence.rdfs:label: OFD1 Mutations Reduce Interaction with Lebercilin

evidence.dc:description:
Mutations
in LCA5 cause LCA, an inherited condition of very
early-onset childhood blindness that is due to retinal degeneration
and also belongs to the ciliopathy spectrum.We also
show that X-linked recessive mutations inOFD1 reduce, but
do not eliminate, the interaction with lebercilin and do not
affect ciliary localization in cell lines, whereas X-linked
dominant OFD1 mutations completely abolish binding
with lebercilin and disrupt ciliary localization as well.
evidence.rdfs:label: Coimmunoprecipitation

evidence.dc:description: The ciliary organelles are present in many cellular types throughout the human body. Cilia defects adversely affect numerous critical developmental signaling pathways essential to cellular development.
evidence.rdfs:label: Autophagy promotes cilia biogenesis by regulating OFD1

evidence.dc:description:
In contrast, the OFD1 syndrome-associated
p.N630fs and p.S586fs mutant proteins localized diffusely
throughout the cytoplasm and showed only a limited,
severely reduced concentration around the basal body
(Figures 6M–6R). The p.I784fs mutant protein, which is
also associated with OFD1 syndrome, showed comparable
scattering throughout the cytoplasm but showed clear
concentration at both centrioles (Figures 6G–6I). This localization
obviously differed from the pericentriolar localization
observed for wild-type OFD1 and for the XL-JS and
SGBS2-associated mutant proteins
evidence.rdfs:label: Localization of OFD1 Mutants upon Mutant Overexpression

evidence.dc:description:
OFD1 depletion
at centriolar satellites promotes cilia formation in both cycling
cells and transformed breast cancer MCF7 cells that normally do
not form cilia.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cilia formation in MCF7 cells

evidence.dc:description:
If OFD1 accumulation at centriolar satellites is responsible for the
ciliary defects in Atg5-/- MEFs, we would expect that depletion of
OFD1 by RNA interference might rescue these defects. In Atg5-/-
MEFs stably expressing OFD1 short hairpin RNA (shRNA), with
about 50% efficiency of overall depletion of OFD1 (Extended Data
Fig. 8a), OFD1 remained at centrioles but was lost from centriolar
satellites (Extended Data Fig. 8b-d). Primary cilium formation upon
serum starvation was fully restored in these cells; nearly 70% of cells
formed a cilium and the length of these cilia was comparable to those
formed in Atg51/1 MEFs (Fig. 3b).
evidence.rdfs:label: 24 h serum starvation and Immunofluorescence

evidence.dc:description: complete

Prenatal death in males. Dysmorphic faces and brain malformations, with polycystic kidneys in females
Laterality was randomised in brain, heart and viscera
Shorter cilia, irregular motility, slower
evidence.rdfs:label: KO Zebrafish model

evidence.dc:description: The disease is inherited as an X-linked dominant male-lethal trait. Using a Cre-loxP system, we generated knockout animals lacking Ofd1 and reproduced the main features of the disease, albeit with increased severity, possibly owing to differences of X inactivation patterns between human and mouse. We found failure of left-right axis specification in mutant male embryos, and ultrastructural analysis showed a lack of cilia in the embryonic node. Formation of cilia was defective in cystic kidneys from heterozygous females, implicating ciliogenesis as a mechanism underlying cyst development.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ofd1 KO
